reviewText:
Despite the fact that for me the pc version is broken, I managed to get the game on the psn, the only difference between the ps2 and pc version is that the ps2 has clunky controls that take some getting used to, the controls on the pc version are fine, the lighting is better on the ps2 version, though on the pc everything is sharper and has higher texture quality.

The story is that you play as a death row inmate called James earl cash, who was meant to be executed but it turns out it was only a sedative and a man only heard through an ear piece called “The director” has gotten the city overrun by gangs of criminals and forces you to participate in a snuff film.

Manhunt is a third person stealth game where most of the time you go from point A to B or have to complete a certain objective. The stealth mechanics are that you hide in shadows to avoid being seen which you will know when it’s dark enough by a contact sensitive icon of Cash will turn blue. The only time an enemy will know where you are hiding is if they see you going into a shadow or if they bump into you. Sound is also another huge part of the stealth: if you run, bump into something, slam doors open, or fire a gun, that will create some noise and the amount of noise is determined by how large the red circle is on the radar. One way to lure enemies out of their spots is to use a lure object being either a brick, a glass bottle or a decapitated head, or by hitting a wall. When an enemy hears you they will start searching for you, if you wait long enough they will give up and go back to their spots or patrolling as normal, if they see you they will attempt to kill you. There are two types of combat in this game: melee, and fire fights, for melee combat you have quicker attacks and heavier and you can block though the melee combat is tricky and difficult since you aren’t a close combat power house and the enemies will call the rest and group up on you and you will most likely be beaten to death, so melee combat is best to be avoided and its only worth doing it if you have a good enough melee weapon and it’s a loan enemy and you have no other choice. Gunplay in this game is half cover based and the other half is using tactics such as the old round the corner murder cue trick, you get a fairly small range of weapons in this game being, pistols (revolvers, locks, and desert eagles) submachineguns (an Uzi) assault rifles (an m16) shotguns (sawn off and a spas 12) and a sniper rifle. Most of the time you will be aiming for headshots though body shots are good if you have a shotgun or a machinegun. Even though you have combat the main focus is using stealth by sneaking up on enemies and murdering them with any kind of sports equipment, kitchen appliance, garden tool and sometimes objects such as plastic bags, glass shards, and barbed wire. There are three levels of brutality with the stealth kills which you increase by holding the attack button down when behind an enemy. The three levels are: white, yellow, and red. White is meant to be quick and clean, yellow is meant to be more violent, and red is meant to be the most violent you can do. The violence in this game is quite realistic, they have realistic sounds for beating, stabbing, slashing, blood spurting, skull cracking, and the choking and cries of pain from the enemies. It isn’t that bad or uncomfortable to watch (Manhunt 2 is way worse) but that’s coming from someone with a lot of experience with video game violence, I’ve played the worst of the worst.

This is also a very difficult game and the difficulty increases with each new gang and set of enemies you will come across in the next few chapters; the AI becomes smarter, they search for you longer, they start getting better at working in groups, they get better at melee combat, they are more accurate shots in gunfights they will have quicker reactions in gunfights and they are better equipped.

This is also a horror game, it uses horror in a somewhat unique way since this game is highly grounded in reality (there are no super natural elements) the environments are unsettling in terms of how close to real life they are in terms of how rough it is, they are fairly creepy, there are a lot of disturbing sights such as ripped and torn body parts, hanging bodies, body parts used as decoration, and just gore lying around. This game also has an extremely dark, grisly, and gritty atmosphere which is aided massively by the music. I just love the atmosphere in this game, the only game which I can think of that has a similarly dark, gritty and grisly atmosphere is condemned criminal origins. And the last mission which I won’t spoil.

There aren’t really any outright problems with this game, one chapter near the beginning can get a bit boring due to the fact that you usually only have one melee weapon and you’ll see the same kill animations over and over and that the environment in that section is the most dullest in the game (it’s a junk yard).  This is also a very unappealing game and the violence, tone, and subject matter can be a huge off putter depending on what kind of person you are, and you might end up in an argument arguing whether this game is completely sick and should be banned worldwide!!

The one thing this game will be most remembered for is the controversy: this game created tons of controversy because people thought it was so violent and gory and the fact that you use everyday objects and in this country (the UK) the game was blamed for inspiring a murder, this case remained controversial for years after even though the Police at the investigation clearly stated that it was a drug related robbery and not the game and it was the victim who owned the game. Now the only thing that is gory in this game are decapitations and cranial explosions. Many people around the world think this is the most violent game ever made, it's far from that, even for the time this is nothing when it comes to how violent a game could be, this came out in 2003, the same year postal 2 came out which is quite possibly the most violent game to date and the previous year soldier of fortune 2 came out which is quite possibly the most realistically violent and one of the goriest games to date.

This is a great game in my opinion and you should try it if you’re not the kind of person who protests “BAN THIS SICK FILTH!!!”

reviewText:
A gorefest of a game packed full of a large variety of brutal ways to eliminate your enemies, Manhunt will always hold a special place in my heart.  The dark story and its setting will keep you engaged as you face off against staggering odds and do whatever it takes to survive.  A gang of skinheads, an asylum full of raving lunatics, and a company of ruthless merceneries are only a few of the organization that are gearing up to end your life.

Fortunately, there are a few advantages that you have over the competition.  Shadows help to even the odds by allowing your to hide from your far better equipped enemies and get the jump on them when they turn their backs.  There are also a variety of weapons, many of them improvised, just waiting for you to get your hands on them,  These can be used for several vicious stealth executions each that include such gems as shards of glass into the eyes, decapitating someone with a garrote wire by sawing off their head, and the end of a crowbar smashed through a skull.  There's a reason there was such an uproar when this game was released.

I highly recommend this game to fans of stealth games as the mechanics are absolutely brilliant.  The horror crowd might also want to get in on this because of the sheer brutality of what you can do to your enemies.  However, those of the squeemish variety might want to stay far away from this.

The game does work on more modern versions of Windows, by the way.  Take a look over at the Steam forum for this game and look up your operating system.  Enjoy!

Manhunt is a pretty old game. It came out two gens ago, on the PS2. I had never played it until it was 2 and a half dollars because of the Summer Sale. I just have one thing to say. BUY IT NOW.

In this game you hunt men, the title explains it. What it doesn't say though is that game is a stealth-action game, with thriller elements that almost make it a horror title also. This game is grim and dark. But for a game with dated graphics and toe to toe combat system, this game is great.

This game is all about killing the bad guys, and if you want a good score, killing the bad guys as brutally as you can. You have melee weapons such as crowbars, baseball bats, machetes, hammers, etc. You also have ranged weapons such as nail guns, shotguns, pistols, SMGs, assault rifles, and yes, a sniper rifle so you can feel like an assassin. This game has a LARGE arsenal of weapons. You just need to find them and equip them.

The game feels great for an older game. You don't need a good PC to play it (trust me, my laptop sucks), and it just feels great. The atmosphere is very dark and intimidating. The enemies are intimidating. This whole damn game is intimidating. The brutal kills you can pull off are extremely violent, so I'd recommend not looking if you are squeemish. If you like violent kills like I do, then this game is great.

The game is really difficult. If you play a lot of stealth games it is probably easier for you, but I found this game to be hard. Now don't worry, it isn't as hard as Dark Souls, but believe me this game is a challenge. I have found myself getting ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off multiple times because an enemy turned around at the wrong moment and noticed me preparing to execute him. But you can start off from the last save point and see if you can kill him correctly that time. The good thing is even though I got mad at this game, once I got a kill, the kills are so violently satisfying that it wipes away all your anger with the satisfaction of slaughtering you enemies unexpectedly.

I HIGHLY recommend this game. You'll have to replace the exe. file and download a patcher for it, but it isn't hard and it is totally worth it. Just buy it. And did I mention the violent executions? Seriously, they're metal as ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
There is much to be said about manhunt. If you do not already know, this game was surrounded by tons of controversy, this is the singular game your soccer mom does not want you to play. If you do not know the story behind the controversy, grab a drink and get comfortable, because this is a long and interesting story. When the game was first released, nobody really paid much attention to the game, critics gave it mixed reviews and the game almost fell into the category of overlooked. But of course this did not happen, on July 28th 2004 14 year old Stefan Pakeerah had been brutally murdered by his best friend Warren Leblanc. Now, when something like this happens, we as humans go through what I call a “moral panic”, meaning when we have been wronged in some way it is so much easier for us to find a boogie-man to pin all of our problems on, so that way we don’t have to take responsibility for these tragic actions. And in this case Leblanc’s parents had their own moral panic and rather take responsibility for not noticing their kids dwindling mental stability, they found their sons copy of Manhunt, a perfect boogie-man to go to court with. Fortunately the 50 million pound (or 81,156,500 dollar) lawsuit was dropped, however the controversy never went away and has since then followed Rockstar Studios to this day.

Now on to the game itself. The gameplay is very violent, and you will be murdering in systematic and unique ways. Honestly, in my opinion, it’s really not that bad. There are so many other violent and brutal games out there that make this game look like Super Smash Bros. in comparison. It is a stealth based game so you will learn to work on baiting your enemies into a trap where you will slowly pick them off 1 by 1, engaging head-on will get you absolutely nowhere. The AI can be a bit frustrating with their dead on aiming and their ninja reflexes, but bear in mind this is a very old game and the AI is very simplistic by our standards. Don’t let that be a turn off, the plotline mysterious and ominous.
Overall I would highly recommend this game to anybody who is looking for a fun and plot oriented action game. This game really did not deserve all the controversy it received and I think it’s a real jewel that has slowly faded out of the spotlight.

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: Because Windows 7 sucks ♥♥♥♥, and I can't really play this game anymore; most of this review is going to be from memory; as I've been coming back to this game for many years.

Ahh, Rockstar... they know how to really rake in the cash, because they've been able to exploit something that will make them a lot of CHA-CHING!: Controversy. Whether it be Jack Thompson going up in arms about killing multiple people with a press of a button, or Hilary Clinton getting her dirty panties in a twist about the scandalous Hot Coffee mod in San Andreas: Rockstar loves to make games that shock people, and nowhere is that more prominent than this sometimes overlooked classic: Manhunt.

The story is that you're playing a bad, bad, baaaad boy named James Earl Cash who was supposed to be executed for the extreme crime of an elaborate plot device, the serum that he was supposed to be injected with was switched out; only putting him to sleep for some time. If he wants to get out of this city, he's going to have to listen to Starkwheather, a director of a snuff film that James is unknowingly taking place in.

The graphics are pretty dated, as you'd imagine. The gameplay is your standard stealth gameplay at first, you hide in the shadows like a gothic homosexual and sneak up on people; executing them with bags, rope, bats, clubs, or whatever is around. The main reason this was given so much controversy is that you have control on how gruesome you want the executions to be. To simply suffocating someone with a blue Wal-Mart bag to painting the walls with someone's brains using a baseball bat. When you're not training on how to become your friendly neighborhood serial killer, you'll be taking place in some good ol' fashioned cover-based shooting. A nice touch.

The main thing I love about this game is the art and sound direction. The whole game is filmed like an imported snuff film, such as intense camera static during executions, to gloomy film grain in the normal camera. I also love the soundtrack because it's synth-y, ambient, dark-wavey tones are reminiscent to that of John Carpenter (The Thing, Halloween, Christine, They Live).

If you're looking for a game to shock someone (or your parents) then this game is for you.

reviewText:
Several years old now, Manhunt upon release created a seismic moral storm within the video-game world with the player assuming the role of a reprieved convict given a second chance, only by acting out in ever more extreme scenarios, the sadistically violent and perverted, murderous whims of a depraved psychotic sociopath.

While some may say 'a game is just a game' and that existential questions of the rights and wrongs of human behaviour  should have no bearing upon a mainstream product of entertainment for society, such a viewpoint is dangerously nihilistic and simply serves to shroud human consciousness in darkness. The mahatmas of India, who are beings beyond the mind, state unequivocally that the purpose of human existence is to love, and even people in the world who are considered to be at the extreme end of the cruellest still themselves do not want to suffer and do not want others to hurt them.

If the designers at Rockstar Games would attempt to sneer at the above by stating that criticising a game for lacking a healthy moral outlook is merely hollow sanctimonious preaching rather than an attempt to make the world a kinder place, then perhaps they should look inside and ask themselves what good is given to humanity buy this product? Violence in games is one thing and certainly can be stimulating and exciting. Yet, in a wargame even though one is killing, at least there is some justification for it in that whichever side you are on the soldier feels he is killing at least to right a wrong and therefore for a good purpose. However, this game revels in and celebrates killing purely for its own sake with the sole intention of inflicting pain also for its own sake. This attitude is neither healthy nor helpful for people to imbibe.

In addition, putting aside these fundamentally important questions, simply as a game, Manhunt is not just morally bankrupt but also poverty-stricken in terms of gameplay. Although the environments of dark streets and back alleys are atmospheric and immersive both visually and aurually, everything is made far too easy and the player is treated like a child and led by the hand, albeit simply to perform acts of killing which, although certainly distasteful, are largely bereft of any skill, and fundamentally vacuous and dull.

I read much of the press about this game for many years before I played it and now, having done so, although I can agree with the moral viewpoint taken by magazines such as the brilliant PC Gamer, I find it surprising that Manhunt's entirely uninspiring game-play managed to still get it a reasonably high review score. Well, erm, as you can see, dear reader, it certainly doesn't get high score from me.

reviewText: Chances are, the only reason you've heard of this game is because of the controversy over the violence, and there's a good reason for that. You know those parts of some games where it suddenly decides it wants to be a stealth game, and it makes you play with poorly cobbled together stealth mechanics for a little while and even if you're a big fan of stealth games it's hard to enjoy it because the mechanics are so poorly designed? Manhunt is like that, except that they forgot to make the rest of the game that's actually fun. It's an extremely simple, basic stealth game where almost every environment is a bland, featureless alleyway or concrete building, and lacks any sort of story beyond what's in the steam description. Along the way you have to deal with other gameplay favorites such as two escort missions and a section where if you get spotted 4 times, the episode fails. It's a game where the only reason to play it is the violence, but even that is pretty tame by today's standards - I could see it being edgy enough to be a decent gimmick in 2003, but in 2015 after you've seen the first two or three strong executions you'll probably just wish they had a skip key so that you wouldn't have to watch any more, since they have barely any variety and aren't particularly graphic. It's just overall an extremely boring game, and I can't recommend it to anyone for even $10 unless you played it back then and are just desperate to relive your 2003 days.

Take a look on the community help section before you purchase this game; unless you're running an antiquated operating system, you're going to need the assistance. Patch download links (as well as instructions on how to run and install the patch) are available in the community help section; you can also find a link to a complete file that includes both the patch and the occasionally needed cracked version of the application. You'll also find directions for installing the cracked version in your Steam account. Most of the time, the information you need to run the patches and application replacement are right there with the download links. Sometimes not. I had to experiment for an evening to get the game ready to run. You'll also need a game profiler (like Pinnacle) in order to use a game controller. Otherwise, you're stuck with the mouse and keyboard. Lots of work to get up and running, but Manhunt's gory goodness is worth the effort.

Patch download links (as well as instructions on how to run and install the patch) are available in the community help section; you can also find a link to a complete file that includes both the patch and the occasionally needed cracked version of the application. You'll also find directions for installing the cracked version in your Steam account. Most of the time, the information you need to run the patches and application replacement are right there with the download links. Sometimes not. I had to experiment for an evening to get the game ready to run. You'll also need a game profiler (like Pinnacle) in order to use a game controller. Otherwise, you're stuck with the mouse and keyboard. Lots of work to get up and running, but Manhunt's gory goodness is worth the effort.
